title: Do book editors get royalties? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A Do book editors get royalties? Generally, no, but that depends upon a lot of things, like the contract the editor has. I generally make a big stink about reading and, more importantly, understanding any contract before you sign it. I also point out that you should ALWAYS have a contract, even when doing business with family or friends. Even though 90% of the time you won’t need it, that other 10% of the is a life-changing mess and you damned well better beleive you needed it. So, editors. What kind? Did you hire them to edit your book? Read the fine print in the contract. They should not get a percentage of anything, in my opinion. You pay them, they do their job, you are done. An editor for hire who tries to slip in a percentage of future earning is a sneaky bastard I wouldn’t do business with. Much like an agent who wants a percentage of ALL future earnings, not just the ones they negotiated for. No one deserves a piece of all the pies except the creator of the work. An editor with a publisher you are publishing with probably should not either. No matter what they earn, it should come out of the publisher’s percentage. That is part of what being a publisher is. The publisher assumes all costs. This does not mean that they don’t earn off of the royalties, it just means it does not affect the percentage the writer earns, like an agent does. It is entirely possible the publisher has a deal with the editor that they earn based upon what the books do. This would especially apply to acquisition editors. In real life? Modern Indie publishers and small presses or micro publishers or whatever are trying to carve out their own niche. They don’t have a lot of money and are doing the best they can. I have seen contracts where the publisher takes their cut and then an additional cut is taken from the author’s royalties to pay the editor. I don’t know that I agree with that, but some are fine with it. It is a “new” way of doing business. Don’t like it? Fine. Read your contract and understand it and don’t sign it. All contracts are negotiable. Even if the final negotiation is that you don’t sign it.

It happens very, very rarely. If a book editor has had a really significant role in the creation, planning, management, style, direction and so on of a major work, they may get some consideration and a (small) percentage of sales. For instance the Editor of a large encyclopedia might be paid a fee by its publisher but also be offered some sort of royalty as a reflection of the long-term work and commitment (preparation of this sort of title can take many years). The people like me - who dot the is and cross the ts in manuscripts written by other people and prepare them for publication - never get royalties. We work on a flat-fee basis (or if we’re really lucky, an hourly rate); we don’t expect anything more than that. I know someone who has managed a series of books (and its online satellites) for over 20 years now. While he works freelance for the publisher, he is effectively the curator of the entire series and is responsible for most of the publishing administration, as well as the list-building, general management and detailed work on each individual project. In respect of this work he has negotiated a deal where he is paid a fraction of his normal hourly rate for the day-to-day work, but is also paid a royalty on sales. Apparently this works very well for all concerned but it isn’t by any means common; it reflects his very, very close involvement with all aspects of the project.

As a freelance book editor, I got paid royalties for the first book I ever worked on. However, this is the exception rather than the rule, and it’s the only book I’ve got paid royalties for. Most self-publishing authors pay their editors an agreed amount rather than offering royalties—and it makes sense for both the author and the editor to agree to this. On the author’s side, if the book sells extremely well, they might give up a potentially large sum of money to the editor. On the editor’s side, if the book sells extremely poorly, the editor might earn barely anything, or worse still, nothing at all. In the case where I got royalties for editing, it was a slightly unusual situation. The publisher was relatively small and didn’t provide their own in-house editorial team, and the author couldn’t afford to pay an editor up-front, so they split their own royalties to ensure I’d get something for my efforts. As it was the first book I’d ever worked on, I was happy to add the book to my profile and less concerned about earning anything from the project, so it worked out well for both of us. On the whole, editors don’t get paid royalties unless it’s an unusual set of circumstances.

Book editors do not get royalties on the books they edit. With traditional publishers, editors are employees of the publishing companies and they get a salary. With self-published books, editors are often not provided. In this situation wise writers will often hire their own editor, which are paid for by the authors themselves. Agents, on the other hand, do get a percentage of an author’s pay. The important thing here is to make certain you carefully read your contract so that you know, and understand, who gets how much of your earned money. If you are new to the writing game, you would be wise to hire an appropriate attorney to go over your contract and make certain all is right.

“Editor” has different meanings that apply to this answer. A typical editor, the ones who work behind the scenes to edit the manuscript of an author, do not get royalties. They are hired for a fee by the author and/or publisher, or they are part of the paid staff of the publishing house. However, you will sometimes see books with an editor credit on the cover; e.g., for anthologies and compilations. There might be many dozens of contributors to the book, so the editor is the equivalent of the “author” of the book. In these situations, the cover-credited editor may get royalties. (The behind-the-scenes editors — who edit the editor’s work — wouldn’t get royalties.) Thanks for the A2A! [Answered: Do book editors get royalties?]

Generally no. However, the editors of anthologies of collected stories by several people generally do get royalties, because they have to do a lot of work to pitch it to publishers, find writers willing to contribute, organize contracts, and put the thing together.

I don’t believe so. If you’re publishing with a traditional house, they employ editors. The publishing company gets the royalty, not the individual person. If, however, you hire your own editor before submitting or self-publishing, the editor would get a royalty if you had agreed to it beforehand and put it in your contract.

In the US, not usually. There are some types of “editors” who do, but they’re not the norm for trade books (defined as all fiction, and general interest non-fiction). You should ALWAYS read the contract to find out what you’re giving and what you’re getting for it. ALWAYS.

When someone edits a compilation book or nonfiction book they might. It depends on the contract. With fiction books it is also by contract with the writer. If the editor works for the publisher or magazines, then they answer is probably no, since they are an employee in a work-made-for-hire situation. They get a salary not a royalty.
Sort of - their salary comes from the sales of the publisher's books, along with the rest of the company staff. If you mean well someone edit your self published book for royalties, a good one won't.
No. They get a salary if they work for a publisher, and if they are freelance editors, they are paid by writers to edit and assess their work.
Not usually. I’ve never accepted a royalty offer, but a couple of times authors have sent me a “bonus” because their book earned well.
Usually editing is work-for-hire. Unless you had a different agreement with them, your editor will receive a payment for the work they do, no royalties.
No, not as a rule. Some freelance editors might take some or all of their pay in the form of a royalty share, but this is highly unusual.
Short answer: No. If by some chance the author agrees to it, which is doubtful, editors do not get royalties from book.
No, they are paid a salary by their publishing house. Either contracted as freelancers or steady salary as a regular employee.
As a rule, no. They charge for whatever editing services you request. All the best.
